Author: molab#4930

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: hard to say, in my opinion you must have downloaded something that got access to either your wallet.dat or your clipboard

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: if possible keep the wallet separate from your everyday / mining computer.

Author: 𝙊𝙞𝙣𝙠#3612
Content:
Let me post my suggestions here too:
>>> @molab If those transfers out of your wallet have not been done by yourself your address is compromised, so I suggest these actions:
1) Stop all transfers to this address (change mining / payout address as soon as possible)
2) Transfer all funds in this wallet to a newly created different wallet on another system (like Verus Mobile).
3) Remove this wallet and the wallet software from your system.
4) Check your system thoroughly on malware (which is a likely cause of that address being compromised). Use consequtive sweeps with different Malware / AntiVirus / Rootkit scanners.
5) If you are convinced your system is clean, reinstall Agama to create a new (uncompromised) wallet.
6) Transfer funds to your new wallet and adjust mining addresses to it.
7) make regular backups of your `wallet.dat` and/or WIFs to a secure, off-line device.

Author: 𝙊𝙞𝙣𝙠#3612
Content: Never use your WIF to log in to any untrusted application, like a webwallet, explorer. And never give anyone access to your private keys.

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: and when downloading miner software make sure you are downloading from the official github channels, don't download from anywhere else.

Author: Arno#3334
Content: What's the derivation path of Agama Wallet addresses? The problem is that when you enter the same 24 word seed into Agama and bip39 tools, different KMD addresses are derived. The path of the bip39 tools is m/44'/141'/0'/0/0. So what's the path of Agama? Just want to make sure to be safe just with the seed even without Agama, but if I use Agama's addresses, I cannot find them anymore with bip39 tools, which feels dangerous to me.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
Agama address generation doesn't follow bip39
it is something unique for the komodo ecosystem

even if agama wasn't available, all the other wallets in komodo ecosystem support the passphrase

it is even baked into the komodo core daemon itself
```
./komodo-cli help convertpassphrase                                                                                                  

convertpassphrase "agamapassphrase"

Converts Agama passphrase to a private key and WIF (for import with importprivkey).

Arguments:
1. "agamapassphrase"   (string, required) Agama passphrase

Result:
"agamapassphrase": "agamapassphrase",   (string) Agama passphrase you entered
"address": "komodoaddress",             (string) Address corresponding to your passphrase
"pubkey": "publickeyhex",               (string) The hex value of the raw public key
"privkey": "privatekeyhex",             (string) The hex value of the raw private key
"wif": "wif"                            (string) The private key in WIF format to use with 'importprivkey'

Examples:
> komodo-cli  convertpassphrase "agamapassphrase"
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "convertpassphrase", "params": ["agamapassphrase"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:7771/
```  
the wif format is the universal format and will work in all wallets

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @Arno ^

Author: Arno#3334
Content: WIF is just the private key for a given address, right?

Author: Arno#3334
Content: regardless of seed words

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
wif means "wallet import format" 
it is the privatekey in a form that can be imported into any wallet that supports KMD

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
> regardless of seed words
yes

Author: Arno#3334
Content: What about atomicDEX's incapability of importing a 24 word seed? Or Agama not offering 12 words to generate? Already in that regard the wallets seem not so compatible

Author: Arno#3334
Content: And you can't import a WIF into atomicDEX

Author: Arno#3334
Content: So in some cases you have to rely on seed words

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
> atomicDEX's incapability of importing a 24 word seed
you can use agama's 24 word passphrase in atomicDEX and viseversa

Author: Arno#3334
Content: with "custom seed" enabled?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
> So in some cases you have to rely on seed words
this is true right now
in regards to atomicDEX
but, it will definitely support wif import before it comes out of beta

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
> with "custom seed" enabled?
yes

Author: Arno#3334
Content: so with a regular bip39 tool it is impossible to retrieve from a 24 word seed the keys and addresses that would be used in the Komodo ecosystem?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
not the default ones atleast
the ledger wallet uses bip39 address for KMD also

Author: Arno#3334
Content: ok
